<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.2 is: Functions shall not call themselves, either directly or indirectly.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.

<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_uio_dev_irq_ack:
```c
static void metal_uio_dev_irq_ack(struct linux_bus *lbus,
				 struct linux_device *ldev,
				 int irq)
{
	(void)lbus;
	(void)irq;
	int irq_info = 1;
	unsigned int val;
	int ret;

	ret = read(ldev->fd, (void *)&val, sizeof(val));
	if (ret < 0) {
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_ERROR, "%s, read uio irq fd %d failed: %d.\n",
						__func__, ldev->fd, ret);
		return;
	}
	ret = write(ldev->fd, &irq_info, sizeof(irq_info));
	if (ret < 0) {
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_ERROR, "%s, write uio irq fd %d failed: %d.\n",
						__func__, ldev->fd, errno);
	}
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function metal_uio_dev_irq_ack:
#define metal_log(level, fmt, __VA_ARGS__) ({if(_metal.common.log_handler&&level<=_metal.common.log_level)_metal.common.log_handler(level,metal_fmt(fmt),##__VA_ARGS__);\
})
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
suspicious_frags: metal_log(METAL_LOG_ERROR, "%s, read uio irq fd %d failed: %d.\n",					__func__, ldev->fd, ret);
metal_log(METAL_LOG_ERROR, "%s, write uio irq fd %d failed: %d.\n",					__func__, ldev->fd, errno);
explanation: Only calls that invoke external code can produce indirect recursion and therefore must be investigated. The read and write calls may be wrappers or may trigger callbacks in the environment, so they are included. The two metal_log call sites are included because the macro expands to call _metal.common.log_handler (see the macro definition included), and that handler could (directly or indirectly) call back into metal_uio_dev_irq_ack. Other fragments in the function (local variable declarations, casts like (void)lbus; (void)irq;, assignments of irq_info/val/ret, the return statements, use of __func__ and errno in format strings) are purely local operations and cannot by themselves cause the function to call itself, so they do not need investigation for Rule 17.2.
